Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as I glanced at the notice board during our lunch break. The foreman had posted about an optional safety training session next week. He said it would help us work better as a team, and I knew the others expected me to show up—no one wanted to be the weak link. As I chewed my sandwich, my phone buzzed. It was a message from Farid, a young man from the mosque. He’d mentioned yesterday that he was struggling and would appreciate some time to talk, “whenever you’re free, Imam.” I could hear the hope in his voice, the kind that made me feel responsible for his well-being. I stared at the calendar on my phone, realizing the training and the only time Farid was available overlapped. My coworkers expected me to be reliable, to pull my weight. My community expected me to be present, to guide and listen. I felt the pressure building in my chest, torn between the hard hats and the prayer mats, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
